The problem is that as heist movies go this is about as captivating as watching someone dodge a bus fare. Almost everything about the film is second-rate: the direction, the plotting, the intrusive modernist production design.
By the time 'The Silence of Lorna' reaches its quiet, unusual, reflective finale, the film feels almost spiritual in its investigation of a lost soul.
It's messy and unusual, not always gratifying, sometimes frustrating, always compelling.
This solid doc reminds us how unsustainable the current American economy is.
'W.' is neither coruscating nor edifying - but without the benefit of hindsight, it's probably the best we can hope for.
And, by being so personal in a way that's so honest and so incisive, Davies indirectly offers national commentary that's relevant far, far beyond his old Merseyside doorstep

Imagine how most filmmakers would tell this story and then see 'Hunger': the differences are bold and powerful and restore faith in cinema's ability to cover history free from the bounds of texts and personalities.
A thoughtful portrait of the purgatory of grief that prefers small incidences and exchanges over grand gestures of sentiment and revelation. It's sad - but never cloying.
It ends up being a compendium of bizarre diversions, most of which are utterly surplus to the film's half-cocked desire to stick with the experience and emotions of its main character.

This is a sobering, well-observed film that doesn't fully hit the mark but sets up enough pleasing ideas to chew on regarding ambition, marriage and ideals of how to live one's life, individually and as a couple.
A real gem.
Empathy is one of the dramatist's slyest weapons and Shanley uses it wisely.
This is a fascinating transitional film from an intriguing director at the top of his game.
The film's triumph lies in the two relationships at its heart: the unlikely rapport between the two Erics, little and big, which is unusual, amusing and affecting.
Somehow, because it resists unlocking, it feels more serious, troubling, significant. It's as funny as it's depressing. It's as brilliant as it is baffling.

Not a good film by a long stretch, but there's something so harmless about this debut directorial effort (from a script by Aschlin 'Scenes of a Sexual Nature' Ditta) that to pull it apart would be like savaging a child's first attempt at storywriting.
A film that brilliantly and sensitively buzzes with life and offers its very own take on our world and our city. It delivers in spades attitude, humour, sadness, love, anger and hope.
Pixar triumphs again with a delirious fantasy that has one leg in the real world of hopes dashed and realised and the other in the cartoon tradition of journeying and adventure.
Johnson serves the story well and strikes a welcome tone by taking his subjects just seriously enough. Very enjoyable - but no more than an extended 'Pop Idol' for cinema.
Thoughtful, funny, slightly sad and superbly crafted.

The tender rapport between this film's two leads, 76-year-old Michael Caine and 14-year-old Bill Milner, is reason enough to see this sweet-natured British indie that explores the not-very-sexy topics of death and ageing.

You couldn't call this audacious British debut a success; it's too arch, awkward and over-extended for that. But, oddly, it's those very same qualities which make it arresting to watch and which mark out its two directors as talents to keep an eye on.
Inevitably, this is a sympathetic, one-sided film and its familiar perspective is a nostalgic, sometimes tiresome one that imagines a 'golden age' when grannies could leave their doors open at night.
It's a film that is both insanely funny and a desperate cry for sanity.
By all accounts, Taylor's play was a more experimental piece than this film, in which the production values, like the acting, veer between the acceptable and the stodgy.
Toback steers Tyson through every triumph and disaster you want to hear about, never pretending that the platform belongs to anyone but the man they used to call Iron Mike.
It can be to mix a strange city with devastating loss. It's at once a deeply sad film and a deeply truthful and optimistic one.
The biggest failure is the film's portrayal of the Leeds team: the oddly-coiffured lads are never more than a unit and the calamity of Clough's time in charge too much of a given.
Hardy delivers a committed if showy performance, but there are some awful smaller turns which smell dangerously of homophobia. The whole thing made me want to scrub my brain with Vim.
It's a lightly amusing film but it's also an unchallenging one which reinforces presumptions about kids rather than surprising with new insights. It floats in the shallow end of filmmaking.
A sparkling, clever work whose ensemble cast impresses, surprises, wrongfoots and disappoints you in exactly the same fashion a class might its teacher.
Its issues are infinite and moveable. It's a bold and challenging work.
The script is witty and playful, the casting just right.
'Subtle' is not a word in Tarantino's lexicon. At the film's heart is a fatal attempt to conflate fact with fiction and a celebration of vengeance that's misplaced and embarrassing.
This slick, serious-minded tale of upper-crust vigilantes protecting their gated community at any cost is a nihilistic but thoughtful portrait of a country divided .
He's also helped enormously by a mature, restrained portrayal from Knightley, a masterclass in passive aggression from Fiennes and a performance of tender seduction from Atwell.
David Sington more than makes up for the straightforward nature of his film with the quality of its interviews and plenitude of staggering archive footage.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers must have imagined sparky, engaging conversation between these duos similar to a high-speed tennis bout between skillful pros; what emerges is more comparable to a lazy afternoon table-tennis knockabout in an old people's home.
This exploration of grief in contemporary South Korea plods along adequately and intelligently.
The occasional voiceover from Béart and a slightly mournful score from Philippe Sarde offer some sense of lament, but mostly this unfolds in the moment and is urgent and engaging.
Themes of altruism and selfishness colour the harrowing realism; the camerawork is skilful, with many scenes unfolding in one, locked frame; and the performances are superb.
Seidl's canny mix of professional and non-professional actors delivers a series of performances, major and minor, of genuinely heart-tugging truth and heartening humanity.
That [director] Schroeder doesn't offer simple explanations gives his tale honesty and fascination.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An extraordinary puzzle of a biography that's ripe to be decoded.
Stefan Ruzowitzky's meshing of plot with debate is impressive. His film is compelling and clever.
A claustrophobic and imaginative treat.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Some of the accusations in this documentary by a pair of Canadian filmmakers who initially set out to make a positive portrait, will make your eyes water.
A terrifically stupid film. Dumb, dumb, dumb.
It's certainly a moving film, and many will find its close examination of a father-son relationship particularly cathartic and reflective.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Suicide and the lives of artists are two of the toughest subjects for cinema to grapple with, and 'Control' squares up bravely to both.
Taymor has mistaken a deeply clichéd view of the late '60s for a radical slice of the zeitgeist. Let it be.
Spector, who's a fluid, straightforward director, resists the crutch of music until the final scene when he goes and blows it all by playing something stupid like... a Gary Barlow song.
Partly a study of cross-national relationships and partly a homecoming comedy on Delpy's part, 'Two Days in Paris' neatly balances stabs at both America and the French.
Black comedy with a subtle political edge.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As fun as the film occasionally is, it just plays like a compilation of greatest hits.
Sokurov applies a thoughtful, humanist spin to the Chechen war - or any war - in this quiet mediation.

Mostly, though, Hogg displays a welcome desire to draw on global film influences and ignore the unwritten rules of what British cinema should or should not seek to achieve, especially in the realm of films about the monied and unsympathetic.
For all Anderson's pleasing, refreshing auteur tendencies, the overwhelming feeling delivered by 'The Darjeeling Limited' is of frustration, déjà vu and little progression.
Clumsily shoehorns every hot topic under the sun into a digitally shot drama of high aims, middling production values and low intelligence.
There are some laughs - but the jokes don't come thick and fast. The film's portrayal of friendship is always warm and sensitive.
This celebration of mid-Atlantic compromise is one for the youngest and most forgiving of teenage girls.
A frustrating, oblique and portentous endurance test.
All in all, it's a bit of a snore that falls back on romance when all else fails.
Offers mild, easy pleasures, even if it stalks emotional truths rather than pierces them.
Slowly, surely this composite portrait of Chet then and now (or in 1987, when Weber shot the film) reveals its own depths.
A delightful, curious film that indulges in both the personal and the political and provides a potted history of modern Iran through one woman's experience.
It's a funny film - a surprise perhaps after 'Vera Drake' - and, crucially, it aches with truth.
You won't know whether to laugh or cry.
Too long, not nearly as funny as it hopes, and some plot elements (what's with the sheep?) are extraneous to the improvised mood.

Languid, sorrowful and strange, French filmmaker Céline Sciamma's debut as a feature writer-director is a sensitive and daring portrait of female adolescence that's curious about all longings, sexual confusions and grey areas of desire.
Why in the name of ermine boleros would anyone make such a dull, coy and, worst of all, pretty film about Anne Boleyn?
Baumbach's interest in families - a distinct Baumbachian sort of family - is acute and his observations often painful and delivered with a dry wit.
This is grand-scale studio-work at its most beguiling.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There's something Styxian about the road travelled here that's reinforced with imagery of death that elevates Ghobadi's tale above the everyday.
A build-up of secrecy and anxiety are well-served by Van Sant's chopped-up narrative of the slow reveal, and again the director shows a keen eye for the rituals and worries of teenage life.
No laughs - but still plenty to like in this diverting and insightful thriller that plays out in the higher echelons of the French judiciary and Parisian world of high business.

Ample music - Oasis, of course - and sweeping crane-shots over miserable two-up-two-downs plead for cinematic and social relevance but, really, this is what it is: an hour-and-a-half spent willingly at the side of a fascinating fella.
One of the most shocking, unexpected and daring finales in a long while.
It's the sort of glamour-meets-violence drugs-crime story on which lads' mags thrive: unqualified, over-reverent and hysterical.
[A] short, sweet, slow-tempo Uruguayan film...
Some films don't age well, and no doubt Brief Encounter had more of an emotional effect in the social climate of post-war Britain.
Riseborough's acting offers total commitment in the face of lunacy, but it's a shame she's flapping around in a film with such a terrible script and warped sense of purpose.
This is cinema in quotemarks, tongue-in-cheek storytelling that uses absurdity to hold a mirror to how we live and love.
Foster does great work with rich ingredients, making the most of every eerie smirk and glance.
Mysterious and melancholic.

Wright throws a lot of ideas at Pan, and not all of them stick, but it makes for a refreshingly imaginative experience, and one not afraid of inspiring a little fear in younger audiences alongside the scattergun wonder.
It diverts more than it delights.
Ultimately Luke Davies's script, for all its warm observations on the man behind the myth... feels like a footnote to a footnote in our cultural history.
This is often a seriously fun film with a shadier side that's ripe for unpicking when the curtain drops.
It's what you imagine might have happened if Charlie Kaufman had got his hands on Up in the Air or Lost in Translation.
A distinctly human, ground-level view of conflict.
The film is so tasteful that you might barely realise the story involves a man having his penis surgically removed at a time when such a thing was barely known or possible.
A humane and uncompromising portrait of one boy's experience as a child soldier in an unnamed African country.
It's that all-too-rare beast: a movie that's both important and engrossing.

Its screenwriters ... have Gladiator and 127 Hours to their names, and Everest combines the muscular, sometimes sentimental force of the former with the sense of physical endurance that made the latter so successful.
Anna Muylaert's observations on family relations and invisible-but-firm class barriers are always acute, even if she ultimately mines them for hope rather than horror.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: U.N.C.L.E. has enough style and smarts to make it an amusingly louche summer movie: a cultivated mix of action and wit, suits and cities.
The man who emerged as a robust but sensitive star in the 1950s offers much frank introspection, some of it no doubt inspired by the late-life family tragedies with which Riley bookends his film.
The energy levels are low, not helped in the early stages by the film being anchored by Phoenix's mumbling, laconic mess.
An unusual story, vividly and intelligently told, and one that leaves you with a stirring sense of joy, injustice and hope. If this truly is the end for Loach, he'll be missed.
Johnny Depp is more engaging than he's been in years, even if his performance can feel a little restricted and one-note.
An energetic doc about Essex's manky Mockney messiah.
Fitfully amusing but too tired to convince.
This gripping documentary reels you in, closer and closer, finally playing its hand in the closing moments.
An unpolished gem.
An extraordinary experience, raw and exciting.
There's something unconvincing about the whole enterprise.
Another philosophical and cosmic historical documentary.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Poses sharp questions about the nature of art and who it's for.
Creepy and ambiguous with a winning line in everyday horror.
The city Malick gives us is at once familiar and strange, beautiful and empty, a place where the real and the surreal were born to coexist. It's an otherworldly theater for an otherworldly tale.
The world that Zootropolis creates is intelligent and fascinatingly detailed -- it feels more like a movie by Disney-owned Pixar than a straight Disney film.
Chaotic and crude - but its lack of sophistication feels like a badge of honour.
Stephen Graham and Michael Smiley are both strong presences in this gloomy, atmospheric drama.

What's most winning about The Club is how Larraín manages to allude to the wider structures, behavior and corruption of the church without ever making this claustrophobic, moody and very local story feel anything but crucial, thrilling and disturbing.
A nostalgic reminder of the power of old-school, shoe-leather journalism.
movie_title: Attacking The Devil: Harold Evans And The Last Nazi War Crime (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that Dusty is actually a bit of a sad sack is something a smarter movie could have developed. But director Sean Anders's film tells a basic story in which strutting males repeatedly lock horns to varying degrees of comic effect.
Even if you can't stand the sight of this greasy Jesus, you might warm to the tub-thumping political doc he's made with director Michael Winterbottom.
No, it's not a happy tale. But what survives from 'Birdman' is a compelling, forward-moving, simple approach to storytelling that grips us through stretches of silence and misery.

Can we believe that police officers would let a psychopathic rapist and murderer go free in the name of fighting homegrown terrorism? As an allegory for human-rights abuses during the War on Terror, it's a non-starter.

In what is surely his finest hour to date, Tom Hardy plays both brothers. Much more than a gimmick, it's like watching one side of a mind wrestle with the other -- literally, in one explosive, fun-to-unpack fight scene.
Some of the acting is awkward, but this is a moving story made with compassion.
Russell Crowe as a troubled Pulitzer Prize-winning author is just one of a long list of unconvincing things about this corny, old-fashioned drama.
An important story, of course, but only mildly engaging as cinema.
Anyone with a beating heart will be forgiven for allowing it to break during this unflinching and thoughtful account of the life and death of the soul singer.
The sensitive, inquiring photography is by far this British indie's strongest selling point.

At times, you ache to put the brakes on the chaos, but still Pixar manages to do what it does best, turning the everyday rough and smooth of childhood experience into a thoughtful, inventive adventure.
Sandrine Kiberlain shines in this pacy, Paris-set and just-silly-enough thriller.
At the core of this tender-hearted and moving British indie film is a fascinating relationship between a single mum and her autistic teenage son.
A mature, thoughtful story, grounded in Melanie Walters's intelligent understanding of the woman she plays.
Silver fox Richard Gere is the magic card up the filmmakers' sleeve for this warm if rambling sequel.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Oddly, for a film about triumph over adversity, there's nothing as uplifting as the opening and closing jogs along a windswept beach.
A film that leans on more crime-movie clichés than anyone involved would probably admit.
Only Aardman could find an irresistible movie in industrial amounts of clay and a story of an amnesiac farmer and his flock at loose in the big city.
This fan-made doc about the Welsh slogan rockers is a rough-and-ready DIY affair.
movie_title: No Manifesto: A Film About Manic Street Preachers (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Cinema doesn't come much more exuberant and raw.
What might easily feel loose and inconsequential ends up feeling like sly magic.
Burton lets Waltz run wild, sucking the air out of every scene with his hysterics, and the always-endearing Adams is left looking like a rabbit in the headlights.
Illegal immigration, unequal relationships and gay sex are put under the microscope in this compelling and slyly urgent drama.
Director Paul Katis gives us a sense of the fine line between sanity and madness.
This first-ever movie take on Peru's furriest export is a cuddly triumph.
It's too twee and theatrical to take seriously.
Jacques Tati's 1967 masterpiece still holds up as a feast of subtle sight gags, playful noise and, above all, visual wonders.
The film's stories have a mysterious, collective power that's undeniable.
This is a whale of a movie, grotesque and a little bloated but impossible to ignore.
A bold, beautiful cosmic adventure story with a touch of the surreal and the dreamlike.

Kes is one of the most astute, engaged films about education and what it takes for kids to be excited about learning or passionate about anything, really, whether in the classroom or roaming the fields with a feathered friend.
A sympathetic, inquisitive portrait of the immigrant experience in Europe.
There are some admirable, if hard-to-watch, moments here, but the film's thriller tendencies are as half-cocked as its compassion for the struggles of parenthood.
This ho-hum doc about the late, great American filmmaker Robert Altman is a disappointment.
Has a shaky, peculiarly British charm that still makes it irresistible.
The misplaced screwball energy is wearying.
Director Thomas Cailley conjures up a vivid, unusual world, offering a playful reversal of usual gender roles.
An exciting, unsettling experience blessed with imagination and compassion.
There's more than one elephant crammed into the room during this sympathetic but insufficient footballing portrait.
An impressive slice-of-life drama that's tinged with unease and strangeness

If The Assassin is sometimes agonisingly slow, it's also agonisingly well-crafted, and it's an agony that regularly tips into ecstasy as Hou allows us to be lost in the period, people and places he offers us.
The sheer, obstinate oddness of 'Tale of Tales' sends crowd-pleasers like 'Game of Thrones' and 'The Hobbit' scuttling into the shadows.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An Auschwitz-set drama that's numbing, provocative and impossible to unsee.
A loaded dance of desire.
A lovely antidote to more souped-up modern animation.

There are moments of bad taste black comic brilliance in this feature debut.

This slapdash but endearing doc about the rise, fall and resurrection of '80s pop outfit Spandau Ballet is an inside job, packed with strong archive footage yet lacking anything you'd call truly incisive.
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film of small moments and tiny gestures that leaves a very, very big impression.

A boldly messy and impressionistic film.
An intimate, warm embrace of a film.
This eyes-open-to-the-world NYC crime thriller is cocky, grubby and electric.

movie_review_blurb: An exquisitely crafted drama of seduction, survival and sexual awakening.
A deeply humane film, as well as a quietly hilarious one.

If you're looking for a diversion, you like more gun-play than word-play, and appreciate exotic dancers more than exotic locales in your movies, then Heat, er, Den of Thieves may be just what you're looking for.

In the hands of the wrong director and/or actor, any script, even one this fine, might have been a disaster. Luckily, all involved were up to the task, and have delivered to us a warm, hilarious, joy-filled film. It's just what we all need right now.

Ultimately, I have no doubt that Downsizing will appeal to certain people not bothered by its tone-deafness. However, for those of us who would probably end up cleaning Barbie's Dream House instead of living in it, the film strikes the wrong chord.
Actually, "awkward and forced" is a good way to describe the mishmash of subplots littering the film.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, American Assassin is a film out of its time, so maybe it is past time for films like it to be laid to rest.
Where Rough Night apparently failed, Girls Trip succeeds, perfectly capturing what it feels like when women who genuinely love each other let their hair down together and just have a good time
Of course, the plot is familiar and derivative, but some pithy one-liners and bone-crunching fights more than compensate in a film that's surely bound for guilty pleasure status.
Even the usually reliable Dennis Quaid flounders as a fellow parent in a film that is at least slickly put together but is ultimately a sheer waste of talent.
There's no sign as yet that the perky but otherwise unremarkable Ms Cyrus is going to find it easy graduating from teen star to grown-up actress.
It's all mildly amusing, if fairly obvious, stuff and it's impeccably played by the superb cast. But you can't help feeling that they all deserve something rather more worthy of their talents.
As dull and cumbersome as its title.
movie_title: Confession of a Child of the Century (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It may lack a little in charm and warmth, but the technical brilliance and decent use of 3D go some way towards compensating for the dimensions that the film otherwise lacks.
If you can ignore the ill-judged slapstick and daft plot developments, it makes for diverting enough entertainment.
Shortcomings aside, this rattles along entertainingly and, at barely 90 minutes, doesn't outstay its welcome.
This is clearly breaking no new ground. But it does what it does with some skill and likeability.
The film certainly has ambition and there are some memorable fight scenes, but it also lacks the extra oomph that could have done for Bean's action-movie career what Taken did for Liam Neeson's.
Overall there's enough prehysterical fun to ensure that family audiences won't be disappointed. Just spare us Ice Age 5.
It's so mired in overwrought melodrama that, while it packs a few punches, it fails to deliver the knockout.
Beautiful Creatures is perfect filler for teens left bereft by the end of the Twilight films.
With westerns rarer than hen's teeth, and decent westerns even rarer, this is certainly one that genre fans should seek out.
If you're a military-hardware junkie or an obsessive player of video war games, this is the movie for you, because Act of Valor is nothing less than a ramped-up, live-action version of Call of Duty.
The whales are so appealing, and the fight to free them from their ice prison so excitingly feel-good, that all cynicism is put aside, making this very decent family entertainment.
There are tears aplenty before the three plot strands are brought - rather too neatly - together.
Goon isn't a life-changer, but it is a pleasant little surprise.
Wreckers blends spells of sheer, watching-paint-dry tedium with sparkier inter-sibling stuff and the odd bout of rural rumpy-pumpy.
As a crazy mix of Cinema Paradiso, Cronos and David Copperfield it's unusually stimulating family fare.
A feather-light tale that never really takes off.
It's British, it's kind of fun and, at barely 80 minutes, it doesn't outstay its welcome.
Unfortunately, there's no irony or retro self-awareness about this adaptation, which is played as if the last 30 years simply haven't happened.
This solid chase thriller uses a template that recalls Taken, without ever reaching the same heights.
The film has some bone-crunchingly good action sequences, one decent one-liner and it's all daftly watchable, but one suspects that this is more of a career high point for Statham than for Hackford.
The characters are cornily cardboard, but the cars are unquestionably super, and the racing rather exciting.
If you're in the mood for some undemanding action entertainment, this routine buddy cop caper offers some cheap laughs.
It's a curiosity, perhaps, but it's nicely made, beautifully acted and well worth seeking out.
At two hours, Her is a little too long, but it ably demonstrates Jonze's talent for mature and magical film-making.
Shana Feste's film is as cornily trashy as they come, but kind of fun if you're in the right mood for some undemanding candyfloss or a good old emotional wallow.
Part time-trip extravaganza, part father/son bonding story, Rob Minkoff's film is cleverly written, warm-hearted, fast-paced and fun.
The film flirts brazenly with the clichés of the genre, from covens to creepy clairvoyants, and is contrived and inconsistent.
Overall, this is fascinating stuff.
Sexy and self-aware, with a 1940s-style Brat Pack feel ...
It's watchable enough, but you wouldn't want to pay cinema prices for the pleasure.
It's fun in a dumb kind of way, but it sets feminism back several decades.
Borrowed Time does have its heart in the right place and you'll happily invest in the likeable lead characters.
The film would be more aptly called "Silly Billi" because it's incoherently plotted, with unremarkable dialogue, and consistently fails to amuse.
A sweeping, solid biopic that's nicely acted and evocative of its time, place and prejudice.
If the story doesn't linger long in the memory, director Amit Gupta's loving depiction of food is something to savour.
Alfonso Cuarón brings a darker, edgier, scarier feel to this installment.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Aselton does demonstrate an assured touch in the early character-based scenes, but she lacks the same control when it comes to handling the action.
There are chuckles and moving moments, just not enough of them.
This is part road movie, part romance and part tale of friendship - and all worth watching.
movie_title: Hasta la Vista (Come as You Are) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing tale of machismo and crazy, mixed-up morality, but it's hard to escape the feeling that it was perhaps better suited to the small screen.
It's daft and nonsensical. But it's that silliness and the sheer calibre of cast that ensure this has a certain car-crash watchability about it.
Fast, fun and cutely done, it tells the tale of two turtles who wind up stuck inside a Dubai aquarium and have to pool resources with their fish-mates to escape.
This is one of those remakes that feels like the product of lazy thinking.
Sure, the film has its mawkish moments, but it's a remarkable, well-intentioned tale that deserves to ride its wave rather than to wipe out on it.
An entertaining addition to the recent wave of retro spy films.
Though a stodgy script means the people at DreamWorks and Pixar won't be having any sleepless nights, there's still much to like about this colourful "gnomance" for kids.
Henry's Crime is neither enthralling enough as a heist movie, nor amusing enough as a comedy, making it rather less than the sum of its parts.
It's a fine teen film - and how often do you see those words in the same sentence?
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is competently made, but the decent and disturbing build-up is marred by a melodramatic climax. A pity.
Unless you're a fan of films featuring bouts of explicit love-making, it's likely to come across as nothing more than a self-indulgent bore.
While it may not tell us anything new about the human condition, it is beautifully shot and impeccably acted, especially by screen newcomer Neiva.
Fans of the series will know what to expect, and this ably delivers it.
Director Sophie Fiennes's film is intriguing and beautifully shot, but is not for the casual viewer.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sadly, in relating Kevin Lewis's journey from physically and emotionally abused child to best-selling novelist, Moran displays a tendency towards melodrama that overwhelms the story.
One must question whether it needs to exist at all, ploughing as it does an already well-worn crime-film furrow.
22 Bullets is neatly acted, nicely made and boasts complex characters that have depth.
Though Alan Clarke's original film still has the edge, this perhaps has more relevance for a new generation of cinemagoers.
You know within five minutes of the start exactly where The Switch is heading, but getting there is still a surprisingly entertaining journey.
You don't have to be Welsh to appreciate Separado! ... but it helps.
By and large, this is symphonic fun with a nicely filmed climax of Tchaikovsky's Concerto for Violin and Orchestra in D major.
When in Rome is watchable enough, albeit in a cheesily inept way, but is far less magical than its storyline.
This is war, up close and personal, and the sheer terror of the hapless young men who inhabit the tin-can killing machine is palpable.
The quality of the acting is impressive and serves to at least give some substance to a rather flimsy plot.
Despite a somewhat disappointing finale, this is a must-see for extreme action fans.

MacDonald's perky performance is a distinct plus, especially because Keaton's character is so enigmatic he's unfathomable, while the movie's lack of pace is only partly offset by some very subtle camerawork.

Caine is surprisingly convincing as the septuagenarian avenger, even though it's a little uncomfortable to root for a vigilante, no matter what the justification for his actions. No doubt, fans of Gran Torino will not be complaining.
Accompanying adults might be surprised by how cheesily enjoyable it is. They may suddenly feel rather old, though.
So corny that a cereal company could have sponsored it...
The well-established Big Momma combination of cheap and cheesy chuckles, sex-obsessed banter, and slapstick so broad even the biggest of mommas could easily hide behind it.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are powerful moments, but there are also plodding ones, and too often one is left feeling that this might have made a rather better documentary than a drama.
Khumba isn't original - it's indebted in particular to The Lion King and Madagascar - but younger kids should enjoy the colourful safari.
Rather more quirk than quality.
Partly compensates for its shortcomings by adopting a deeper, more analytical approach to its portrayal of endemic police and political corruption.
The French, perhaps, like this sort of comedy of chaos a mite more than we do, but Beautiful Lies is enjoyable enough.
The lives of football referees and linesmen have always been a bit of a mystery, but this fine, no-frills documentary provides some long-overdue insight.

Yoon's performance, nuanced and subtle, is superb, while the film is long and languid so adjustments and allowances must be made both for its pace and, at times, for its poetry. But the effort is well worth it.
Not quite Horrid, but this Henry comes close. Accompanying adults may wish they'd opted for triple detention.
Four years in the making, this is simply a staggering achievement, with a standard of photography that continues Britain's excellence in the field of wildlife film-making.
Eric Lartigau's film is glossily watchable, but it's hampered by a central conceit that never really convinces, and not even a cameo from screen legend Catherine Deneuve lifts proceedings.
It may not change your life, but it may just make you wonder what your child is up to on that computer, and just who he or she is "talking" to.
The acting from the top-notch cast is good. So, too, is the attention to period detail. The whole thing is just a little dry and ponderous.
Dear, oh dear - there should be a law banning British directors from making so-called sex comedies.
Noel Clarke shines as a cocky prisoner, and the film's best scenes are those in which he goes eyeball to eyeball with D'Arcy's greenhorn guard.
Even younger viewers would surely relish a little more raunch. It's hard to hate, however, and parents can take confidence in the fact that it could never be accused of being a corrupting influence.
The pre-teen angst, sibling squabbles and broad comedy should guarantee that it goes down well with five- to ten-year-olds.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sheen is on good form, the Basque-country locations look great, and the gentle, meditative messages put out make this hard to dislike.

The controlled set-up effectively explores notions of honour and servitude in a time when the bushido era was drawing to a close, before giving way to a terrific, 40-minute climax that's sheer martial artistry in all its mud-and blood-splattered glory.
It's a compelling story of how one disillusioned idealist helped change the world - and all for a Sony Walkman and some Queen cassettes!

This is first and foremost, of course, a high-octane, thrills-and-spills documentary for bikers and biker fans. But it will also be enjoyed by anyone who wants to see likeable loons indulging an obsessive desire for speed.
Bright, breezy and blissfully 2D.
Mars may need moms, but does Earth need this movie?
It's all technically brilliant, but maybe lacking a little in charm and true wit.
The film is poorly directed, edited, scripted, acted and everything else, and does scant justice both to Walker's presence and Belle's prodigious free running skills.
There's a whiff of "TV movie of the week" about this tale of one woman's crusade against injustice, but, like the similarly themed Erin Brockovich, there's also much to recommend it.
Downhill is a home-grown treat, and the perfect solution to anyone seeking an alternative to the preponderance of overblown blockbusters on screens big and small.
This is old-fashioned, no-frills action film-making, the sort of efficient macho-minded entertainment that Berg is good at.
Originality is hard to come by, especially in horror films, but there's a good dose of it in this stylish and beguiling little chiller based on the first book in Dan Wells's YA book series.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's corny, but it also represents an ideal fantasy fulfilment for preteen girls.
movie_title: Molly Moon and the Incredible Book of Hypnotism (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Even those who are too young to remember Zappa's work may be drawn in by his iconic rebel status.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although you need to keep your wits about you here, Your Name is a sharply animated, well-told fantastical tale for tweenagers.
Fans of Alexander Jodorowsky may fancy taking this trip with director Emiliano Rocha Minter; others should avoid at all costs.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Kind of fun, though the material isn't always up to its calibre of cast.
Threaded with a Cinderella subplot and featuring a poppy mix of musical covers and original songs, Trolls is quality confection for little ones.
It's decently acted and decently made. At the same time, though, there's nothing particularly exceptional going on here.
The acting, especially of leading lady Astrakhantseva, overcomes the language barrier, and makes this an adaptation worth experiencing by more adventurous viewers.
A sweatily gripping thriller with a rousing finale.
It's no life-changer, but still offers decent entertainment.
While the first film was attention-grabbing in its portrayal of gang life, Brotherhood is a more accomplished piece of true Brit film-making.
Slickly made and worth the watch.
Despite some languid stretches, it's genial knockabout stuff for slightly older kids that, like Caesar, comes, sees and kind of conquers.
movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (Astérix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: By turns funny, sad, scary and exciting, this is terrific family entertainment, though children who are easily upset may be disturbed by some of the intense action scenes.
A brilliant, often brutal biopic that's cool for cats of any persuasion, whether jazz fans or otherwise.
It's worth the watch, though unlikely to sway the entrenched opinions as to whether what the police did that day was justified or not.
As an adult action-comedy spoof, Keanu does intermittently cut it. And the kitten is really, really cute.
The Ice Age films have always been one of the better, more consistent family franchises. But this is a sequel too far.
Superior and hugely watchable costume drama.
It's more likely to have the viewer giggling in disbelief than gasping with shock.
Though unquestionably a film of faith, Miracles from Heaven doesn't ram its religiosity down your throat quite as much as many others of its kind do. Not until a horribly over-fluffy finale, that is.
The story has pace and vigour, the performances are good and this is Fassbender as you've never seen him before.
Fast-paced, colourful and fashionably girl-powered fun that, while treading no new territory, is perfect entertainment for younger kids.
The result is a slice of delightful escapism that will enchant children and entertain parents as well.
Ghastly piece of soft-core porn from Zalman King, the trashmaster behind the Red Shoe Diaries series.
This is quirkily compulsive viewing.

Plummer and Janet McTeer, as the Kaiser's wife, bring their customary class to proceedings. But they can't save a tepid mishmash that seems undecided whether it's wartime romance, spy drama or fanciful political fable.

The film isn't best suited to those who like their movies with a beginning, a middle and an end that's neatly tied up in a pretty red ribbon. But take a chance, work with it, and this smart British drama will reward the effort.
Like Shirley herself, it's warm and likeable, and a tribute to the octogenarian's triumph over a lack of self-belief.

It's certainly brash and breezy enough to keep youngsters mildly amused, though adults may well agree that it's time to say leggo to Lego, which isn't even an element crucial to much of this underwhelming adventure.
This is a fact-based film that treads no new survival-drama ground, but it's well made, gruelling and watchable.
Kudos are deserved everywhere for a well-written, beautifully played and offbeat piece of re-imagined history that's always funny despite humour sometimes stemming from a distinct sense of unease.

This notorious British gangster tale may have been milked more often than a herd of prize Guernseys, but the shooting to death of three top drug dealers down a remote country lane still attracts film-makers like a cowpat does flies.
There's an odd disconnect between a complex, sometimes dark and occasionally violent plot, and the younger kids that the visual cuteness of its characters suggests it's aimed at.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Truth be told, this is the sort of film that, 30 years ago, would have gone speedily to VHS, and which should quickly suffer the equivalent fate today.
Corny but efficient, and perfectly fine if you're tweenage or early teen, or just seeking a good sob.
Niche but nice.
Sir Patrick Stewart, stalwart thespian and former captain of the Starship Enterprise, voices a poop emoji. Which sort of says it all, really.
Pitched at horror fans who like to be mildly unsettled rather than grossed out, Wish Upon is decently made, but essentially it's a wet-afternoon watch.
You feel a little grubby just for watching it, let alone liking it. This is seriously good film-making, though - just not for the faint-hearted nor weak-stomached.
Pleasingly less prurient and more female-empowered than many "women in peril" creature features.
A real minority watch that's best filed under 'decidedly different, but definitely difficult'.
Should appeal to lovers of period romance with a bit of stamina.
For all its faults, City of Tiny Lights is a strong and stylish bit of Brit-noir with an impressive leading man in Ahmed. Definitely worth investigating.
Neither great nor grim but somewhere in between, this is a film for nostalgic older audiences with fond memories of Dynasty, Shirley Valentine and Camelot.
Cornily heart-warming, it's an absolute delight and a welcome relief from the shock and bore of the typical multiplex blockbuster.
It's all nicely computer-generated, and perfectly watchable. There's just a nagging feeling that a rather better, less formulaic film could have been made of such an engaging idea.
It's a taut and talky film, nicely played by all concerned. But given the big themes, it is a rather small affair with few cinematic qualities.
Kenan skilfully combines familiar scary-movie clichés with more original touches, including an innovative use of drone technology, and comes up with a better-than-average remake.
Like most sequels, Pitch Perfect 2 isn't as good as the original, but it has its moments - enough, just about - for lovers of the first film to like this one too.
Although derivative, Two by Two is bright, breezy, fast-paced fun that will captivate younger kids without offering much for accompanying adults.
movie_title: All Creatures Big and Small (Ooops! Noah is Gone...) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Even if this doesn't go down in cinema history as a great musical, it's certainly well worth a watch and a listen.
It's no barrel of laughs, but there are flashes of humour to lighten the load.
It is nicely feel-good, is less manipulative than it could have been, and is well played by the high-calibre cast.
One or two of the more serious father/son scenes pass muster, but emotional truths are few and far between.
There are enough mirthful moments - many splendidly surreal - to make this a trip worth taking.
This is desperately poor stuff, juvenile in the extreme, thoroughly unfunny, and pitched squarely at younger kids. However, even they will probably find it too long and convoluted.
It's all no doubt breathtaking if you're a Björk fan, but repetitive and rather tough going if you're not.
This traditionally animated, endearingly "low-tech" film is bittersweet, often sad and occasionally very moving.
In trying to appeal to a broad family audience, Alexander sometimes spreads its comedy a little thin. But it's big-hearted and, ultimately, upbeat.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mildly entertaining without offering any great quality, the movie is a half-decent action showcase for the talented Evans, the fight scenes are OK, and there is enough cheese and ham to fill a tasty sandwich.

At 150 minutes, it's way too long, with several superfluous scenes and subplots. On top of all that, moments of high melodrama and overwrought opera suggest that it has an over-inflated sense of its own importance.
The Giver has its moments, but generally fails to convince the viewer of the credibility of the world it inhabits.
Crass and corny ...
It shades into corniness and contrived plot twists, but the film generally does a good job of breathing life back into a well-worn genre.
Dreadful.
Aside from some heavy-handed philosophising about how distance doesn't dilute friendship, this is a superior junior sci-fi yarn.
Snappy dialogue and fast pacing keep things lively, but essentially, this is a video game you can't play, and a film that all but rabid Ratchet & Clank fans will find tough to watch.
Yes, it's the dancing dog from Britain's Got Talent, starring in his wholesome and family-friendly first live-action movie.
Hand-drawn, eccentric and episodic, the film flies in the face of the current trend in animation for computer-generated excess - it's strangely comforting, old-school cartooning.
Driven by some half-decent action scenes, Dino Time is no must-see, but it will comfortably while away a wet afternoon.

The film still contains a couple of classic sequences, most notably Stan's attempt to trick a St Bernard dog into letting him at its brandy keg and Ollie singing Let Me Call You Sweetheart to Stan's sousaphone accompaniment.
A telling portrait of a decent and likeable man who ultimately was too emotionally immature to cope with the twin pressures of fame and fortune.
Every so often, a film comes along that takes so weird a turn that it completely discombobulates the viewer. Spring is such a film.
A worthwhile if sometimes tough watch.
It's all fine without being too exciting.
It may lack the finesse and charm of animation from Pixar, Disney or DreamWorks, but it's a decent yarn for younger kids who want something to watch on a rainy day or school holiday.
Potentially interesting "CSI: Judea" stuff is speedily ditched in favour of Fiennes's conversion to Christianity and some routine miracles.
A mildly diverting confection for a rainy day, and something that may find a more suitable home on the small screen.
The kids may need some persuading. But chances are they'll love this too ...
Slickly made though thoroughly non-critical, Mr Calzaghe should appeal to fans of the Italian Dragon even if it is a bit light on its feet.
The story is so quintessentially Romanian, it had better been made in Romanian, with Romanian actors.
Although first-time writer/director Austin Stark has his heart in the right place and Cage eschews his trademark zaniness, it's only watchable rather than gripping.
It breaks no bounds, offers no edges. But it's a hugely likeable piece of old-fashioned entertainment ...
Chan brings martial artistry to the fight, Cusack his siege skills, and the the film overall is a mishmash of languages, styles and tones.
Terrific slice-of-life stuff, by turns funny and sad, with Ariyan Johnson excellent as an ordinary New York high-school student who's determined to better herself.
movie_title: Just Another Girl on the I.R.T. (1993)

movie_review_blurb: It's worth catching on some platform or other if you and the kids are in the mood for some pleasant Oz escapism.
This Swedish docudrama is a strange but beguiling beast.
The laughs here are way off-target. This Brit-flop won't be bowling anyone over.
Gripping and genuinely moving, Maggie is a film of subtlety with a different kind of horror that tears at the heartstrings more than the flesh ...
A good story, quite grippingly told, and worth consideration.
One of the better recent music-scene films. Niche, maybe, but nice.
Where to start?
There is some genuinely scary stuff ... and if you're a lover of the weird, it's a must-see.
A western, most likely different from any western you'll have seen before, it is by turns funny, sad, tragic, comic and drily witty - it's a gem of the genre.

It is, first and foremost, a visual delight, a Victorian picture book come to life, from its brief prologue in India through its darkly enchanted recreation of Misselthwaite Manor on the Yorkshire moors.
It's Whoopi and the girls who keep this confection tasty.
Robbins eschews leftist diatribes for a bold cartoon version of history. It's as crowded and energetic as a big parade.
I respect it enormously, but it feels like an art film in search of a movie. Mann recognizes the importance of Ali as an entertainer, but he's in danger of forgetting how to be one himself.
Happily, the world is now discovering what a small but ardent cult has known all along-that Jane Campion is one of the most splendid filmmakers around.
Leslie Bohem's script is almost self-parody, but director Roger Donaldson keeps a straight face throughout.
The real mystery here is why a filmmaker as talented and unique as Crowe would want to devote several years of his life to recreating someone else's movie.
Peter Hyams's lurid, FX-happy thriller slams pieces of a dozen other movies into a noxious new compound. It has to be seen to be believed, but who'd want to?
The semifunny Semi-Pro is amiable enough, but you never feel there's much at stake.

Reservoir Dogs is a bad boy's movie, show-offy and more than a little decadent. Its saving grace, and its limitation, is in its cool cartoonishness. It never invites any real emotional identification with these crooks.
Glimcher's movie knows how to let down its hair and live for the night.
The Beach is nothing to write home about, though the landscapes are ravishing. The movie itself is neither fish nor fowl.
It seemed like a good idea, but the more you think about it, the clearer it becomes that The Avengers should never have been turned into a movie.
Neither Crowe, Ryan nor the topical subject keeps Proof of Life from feeling recycled. For all the up-to-the-minute research, the movie still gives off the musty scent of Hollywood contrivance.
Kipling purists may not cotton to Disney's new live-action version of The Jungle Book, but it's hard to think of anyone else who won't be enchanted.
Makes up for its gaps in logic with its breezy tone and its technological razzledazzle.
One can make excuses for a 23-year-old writer's misunderstanding of human behavior, but how could Mike Nichols look at himself in the mirror when he directed such dumbfounding scenes.
The prickly, conservative, jacket-and-tie iconoclasm of Barcelona is like nothing else around.
A striking, unnerving coming-of-age film, "L.I.E." is the rare American movie that isn't afraid of ambiguity or confronting an audience's preconceptions.
It's a wise, moving love story--marred only by a rather arbitrary twist of fate at the end--played out with an emotional honesty that would be unusual and adventurous in any language.
Obviously this is not everybody's cup of weird tea: you must have a taste for the esthetics of disgust. For those up to the dare, it's one clammily compelling movie.
So chic, studied and murky it resembles a cross between a Nike commercial and a bad Polish art film.

The talented Glazer keeps things crisp, clean and purposeful. The only flab on this film is around the waist of its sybaritic hero, a working-class crook who has finally gotten a taste of the good life, and doesn't want to lose it.
No matter how well you know this tale, it still packs a wallop.
Few films have explored the complicated bonds of love and resentment between brother and sister with such delightful honesty.
I won't pretend that Jarmusch's austere poetry will speak to everyone...No matter. This strange, mystical Western is his most daring work -- his best since Stranger Than Paradise.
Yang takes the long view, transforming the ingredients of family melodrama into a serene, generous, comic vision of our tangled urban lives.
Shot and edited with crisp flair, Alice and Martin keeps flying off in unexpected directions, anchored by Binoche's dark, obstinate passion.
The urban Maori milieu, however, is something we haven't seen before, and the images stay with you.
Watching the movie work itself into an operatic frenzy, one remains curiously detached: the grand gestures are there, but where's the music?
Torn between celebration and sendup, CB4 misses its big target as often as it hits.
Conceptually, this savage cartoon ends up as trapped in surfaces as its shallow antihero: it's all dressed up with nowhere to go.
Though Parker's heart, and his facts, are in the right place, he's succeeded in reducing a powerful story of institutional racism into an unforgivably dull film.
It's not the actors' fault that no one is able to break through the film's gorgeous but chilly surface. You watch Casino with respect and appreciation, reveling in its documentary sense of detail.
I wouldn't dream of giving away the ending, but it's not likely to satisfy either the action crowd or Matheson fans.

A real artist could make something incisive or darkly hilarious out of this moral tightrope act. Schumacher, veering recklessly between social satire, kick-ass fantasy and damsel-in-distress melodrama, plays the game for opportunistic cheap thrills.

It takes its old-fashioned soap-opera formula and refurbishes it for the age of Oprah. What that means is that while the script by McMillan and Ronald Bass serves up moonstruck romantic fantasies, it speaks in the language of self-empowerment .
The wait pays off. When the Big Guy starts showing, and begins to get that radiant glow, Junior hits its mellow, endearing comic stride.
This arty melodrama is not likely to make teenage America get down with Shakespeare.
Refreshingly subtle.
These lunar landscapes and grotesque visions are as strange and haunting as a science-fiction fantasy. Would that it were.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Zemeckis has been seduced by the siren call of motion capture... Memo to Zemeckis: come back to earth!
By the tepid ending, the movie appears to have been sedated.
Peaks early, then descends into portentous nonsense.

For all its grit, style and atmosphere, Gangster never sweeps you away. It has neither the lurid bravado of De Palma's "Scarface" nor the intimate grasp of the criminal lifestyle you find in Scorsese or Coppola.
It's both powerful and infuriating, brilliant and facile, hilarious and horrific, witty and demagogic. It's a great movie to argue about.
[It] may be too airbrushed for its own good, but in the end nothing can stop this story from putting a lump in your throat.

It wasn't a bad idea to conceive of the film as an epic, complex love story between Frida and Rivera, but the passion between them is more rhetorical than palpable...Taymor and Hayak give us only the rough sketch of a wild soul.
With this film it becomes clear that Sofia Coppola is a filmmaker with eyes all her own.

Legally Blonde is a broad, glossy teen comedy that shows off Witherspoon's wicked comic talents. Silly? You bet. But if this Popsicle of a movie melts long before it's over, the first half has more good laughs than all of "Sweethearts."

This delicious, seriocomic tale of four friends in affluent, liberal, west L.A. grappling with midlife crises, metrosexual spouses and household remodeling takes on an avoided subject: money, and how it affects our relationships.
This almost-great epic has one foot in legend: it's a vision of an American titan that could have sprung from the insides of Hughes's own obsessive, perfectionist head.
Hirsch, who carries the film on his increasingly emaciated shoulders, performs heroically, but there's an edge missing.
If you're trying to make us believe we're watching 'reality' by using a faux documentary style, you need actors who never look like they are acting, and this is where Redacted stumbles.

Here -- in a Jerry Bruckheimer-produced high-seas adventure that incorporates roaring cannons, oddball comedy, a love story and more than a touch of the supernatural -- Depp unleashes his theatrical bravado. He's hilarious.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There are signs that a lot has been cut, and in trimming his film Brooks may have squeezed too tight: his movie needs breathing space.
Instead of cool twenty-something irony, Smith startles us with raw emotional honesty.
It transformed the way I looked at the world.
Baumbach's closely observed tale of dysfunctional family relationships has the microscopic texture of a New Yorker short story and the darting, spontaneous style of a French New Wave movie.
A Bronx Tale is a deliciously well-observed memory piece about growing up in the '60s that marks the vital debut of director Robert De Niro.
This bittersweet X-ray of American family dynamics may not be a Hallmark-card notion of a holiday movie, but it's one any son or daughter can take to heart.
No two-hour film could ever capture all the riches of McEwan's masterly novel. But Wright and Hampton's Atonement comes tantalizingly close, while adding sensual delights all its own.
To my eyes, the novelty and exoticism of the setting couldn't disguise the hackneyed situations and sentimentalized characters.

if this is what Hollywood considers serious, important filmmaking, maybe the movie industry should stick to the low road. Directed with the in-your-face subtlety of a sitcom, the tone of the movie is weirdly miscalculated from the get-go.
It's frustrating to see such a promising premise, and such a delightful cast, wasted.
Boldly self conscious, Poison switches channels among its three stylistically varied but thematically linked tales with cumulative, claustrophobic power.
An actor for sophisticated palates, Tucci's too good to stay obscure any longer.

That this relentless barrage of psychological and physical torture is extremely well made and powerfully performed -- Watts hurls herself into her physically demanding role with heroic conviction -- somehow makes it worse.
If I were a 10-year-old boy, I'd probably think it was the coolest movie going.
A smart and wicked delight
Out of each of these uprooted characters are spun stories of love, loyalty and betrayal.
Titanic is big, bold, touchingly uncynical filmmaking.
Sergio Sanchez's richly ambiguous screenplay allows you to interpret what you are watching on both a supernatural and a psychological level, and either way is equally unnerving.
The performances are pitched at just the right scale: theatrically exaggerated but untainted by "Broadway" bombast. Who knew Burton would have such an uncanny feel for how to film a musical?
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Forster's solid, unpretentious movie hits its marks squarely, and isn't afraid to wear its heart on its sleeve.
[A] work [of] blistering intensity -- and filmmaking that can make your jaw drop.
Hoffman brings out the best in Hanks -- they riff off each other with delicious comic teamwork.
Not to be missed in any language. In a year that has given us such marvelous animated movies as Ratatouille and Paprika, this vibrant, sly and moving personal odyssey takes pride of place.
Stirring, likable and unashamedly formulaic.
The Diving Bell and the Butterfly keeps opening up, its structure mimicking the awakening of its extraordinary protagonist's mind.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A twisted comedy for twisted times, this movie made me happy. Go figure.
The movie has an emotional kick that lingers like a primal memory. When the year is over, Cuaron's film will be remembered as one of 2002's finest.
The unfussy, tossed-off quality actually helps give this original story zippy irreverence some of Disney's plusher cartoons lack.
The Freshman has a preposterous plot even the writer's mother couldn't believe, and it strains and creaks down the runway, but when this baby gets off the ground, we're talking seriously funny.
A sweet pipe dream, Enchanted April won't bear much scrutiny; just bask in it indulgently like a spring sun.
My Own Private Idaho is a far cry from seamless, but I would gladly trade a dozen well-made studio movies for one of its vital parts.
W. might have had some impact had it been made four years ago. But it's both too late and too early for a movie about our sitting president.
Rachel Getting Married takes a familiar subject -- the raw nerves of American family life with -- and draws fresh blood.
[Director] Sollett is able to take familiar teen tropes and transform them into low-key magic.
Pellington knows, as did the 1940s master of horror Val Lewton, that what you don't see can raise far more goose bumps than what you do.
As the plot grows more intricate, strangely the tension dissipates, until finally the movie just seems to run out of breath.
Gosford is fine, well-groomed entertainment, but the road it takes has already been well paved.
To say this is a great comeback for an actor whose talent was exceeded only by his self-destructiveness is obvious.
Burn After Reading is a blackly comic illustration of Murphy's Law, set in the Washington world of CIA espionage, and populated with a cast of delusional dunces who are a wonder to behold.
Director Charles Herman-Wurmfeld's movie knows what it wants, what its limits are, and delivers its delights accordingly.
The violence in Boyz N the Hood is neither gratuitous nor melodramatic; its aftermath is shattering. Singleton's powerhouse movie has the impact of a stun gun.
A glorious rebuke to all this summer's recycled, effects-ridden, laboriously "fun" Hollywood disappointments piled along the wayside like so many crashed cars.
A winning animated feature that has something for everyone on the age spectrum.
Why is this movie Hitchcock's masterpiece? Because no movie plunges us more deeply into the dizzying heart of erotic obsession.
It's elegantly mounted and never dull -- and always easy on the eyes.

The problem is not simply that Lone's drag wouldn't fool a baby. In the magnified intimacy of the camera's eye, it's clear Hwang doesn't really know who these unlikely lovers are. Metaphors can't carry a movie-flesh and blood is what's required.
Again the Coens take familiar movie tropes and twist them into something new. This may be their most haunting movie.
A movie like this has only one not-so-noble reason to exist: to make us sob. And it just doesn't deliver the goods.
The filmmakers have obviously studied There's Something About Mary, and learned nothing.

Quantum of Solace isn't frivolous or cheesy, but it isn't all that much fun either. Craig is still the right guy for the job, but for his boiling-on-the-inside performance to work, he needs more to play with.

While it obviously struck a deep chord in its homeland, here it's not much more than a light tap on the funny bone. The irrepressibly tacky Kerrigans make an amusing first impression, but the movie essentially has only one joke to offer.

Fearless is the rare commercial movie that raises more questions than it answers. You leave it in an altered state yourself--moved, not quite satisfied, but certain you've seen something out of the ordinary.
The didacticism is, for the most part, gracefully meshed with the storytelling, and the special effects never take over the show.
Eastwood's disturbingly human in Unforgiven, a stunning, dark Western that may stand as the actor/director's summation of the form.
A vampire movie like no other.
Eastwood tells his haunting, sorrowful saga with such a sure, steady hand, only a very hardened cynic could fail to be moved.
The movie has a comfy, lived-in feel; it doesn't beat you over the head for laughs, or take its horrors-of-New York theme too seriously. Smile and enjoy.
Hilarious and deadly, this may be Altman's most completely realized film since his glory days in the '70s.
Lee and company have performed a powerful service: they have brought Malcolm X very much to life again, both as man and myth.
It's about seduction, and either you succumb to its inky entrapments or you resist. When its mojo was working, I was happy to be had.
A good half hour too long, and badly in need of some scares, Hook is a huge party cake of a movie, with too much frosting. After the first delicious bite, sugar shock sets in.

Peyton plays upon Claire's deepest anxieties -- her sexual insecurity, her fear of child molesters -- to vicious effect. Hanson and Silver manipulate our anxieties no less adeptly, but a good deal more playfully.
movie_title: The Hand that Rocks the Cradle (1992)

movie_review_blurb: When was the last time you saw a movie that was quiet, intimate, tender? That let you explore your feelings about the characters without hanging moral signposts around their necks?

It doesn't suffer from the compulsive tidiness of some of Allen's later movies -- the juices are flowing, the hysteria is closer to the surface -- and in this looser, more volatile atmosphere his extraordinary cast gets to soar.
This is the grandest guignol Hollywood has produced in years.
Ready to Wear is all appetizers: the main course never arrives. Still, the critical savagery puzzles me. Altman's movie may be indefensible, but it's not unenjoyable.
Maybe it's only adults who'll get teary-eyed -- kids just wanna have fun. And they will.
Nair's stereotype-shattering movie -- like the polymorphous culture it illuminates -- borrows from Bollywood, Hollywood and cinema verite, and comes up with something exuberantly its own.

Once you sort out the main characters and the plot kicks into action, it becomes clear that under the shameless MTV pyrotechnics lies a structure as intricately crafted as a Feydeau farce. Guy Ritchie has a giddy gift for storytelling.
movie_title: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1999)

movie_review_blurb: You have to pay close attention to follow the double-crossing intricacies of the plot, but the reward for your work is dark and dirty fun.
I've rarely laughed so much at a movie I generally disliked.
Forget the hype. Now for the real question: How's the damn movie? Answer: Pretty darn swell.
Lee is in fine form.
First-time director Frank Marshall has long been Steven Spielberg's producer, and he's learned the master's lessons well.

Hancock's surface-skimming script is too formulaic for the job. There's enough material here for a crisp 90-minute entertainment. At 2+ hours, the leisurely, mildly engaging A Perfect World barely sputters across the finish line.
A comedy, romance and supernatural thriller rolled into one, Ghost is a zippy pastiche that somehow manages to seem fresh even though it's built entirely out of borrowed parts.

Lucidly, dramatically and without resorting to partisan rhetoric, Charles Ferguson's not-to-be-missed documentary "No End in Sight" lays out in convincing, appalling detail the disastrous missteps of the U.S. occupation of Iraq.
This is a very skillfully made corporate product, but I wonder who, exactly, will be fully satisfied.
Chen's remarkable movie uses an unusual love triangle to telescope more than 50 years of tumultuous Chinese history.
movie_title: Farewell My Concubine (Ba wang bie ji) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Working within the constraints of a big studio film has brought out Gilliam's best: he's become a true storyteller and a wonderful director of actors. This time he delights not only the eye but the soul.
Given these fundamental caveats, Deceived is diverting, if disposable, fun. Director Damian Harris knows how to keep an audience's attention.

The good news: there are many twists, turns, subplots and surprises that the coming attractions don't even hint at. The bad news: these twists and turns are so preposterous, or so irrelevant, that they undermine the movie they're meant to tart up.
Leatherheads is laid-back, amiable and terminally tepid.

This movie is about giving us a privileged glimpse of the Stones in action. It's a record of an astonishing musical chemistry that has been evolving, with no signs of calcification, for nearly five decades.
Fluff with an edge, Four Weddings brings a venerable old genre delightfully up to date.
Hoop Dreams has shown us that the rules of the game are stacked against kids like Gates and Agee. Even better, it shows us how they fight back, with the inside moves of hope.
It has a generosity toward all its characters that rescues it from predictability.
It is just another dreadful teen horror flick--albeit one gussied up with self-conscious notions about the thin line between perception and reality.
Baby Mama is formulaic, but this broad odd-couple girl comedy has the advantage of knowing what it is.
Iron Man may not be distinguished enough to convert you to the cause. But Downey and Favreau give the movie a quirky flavor it can call its own. For that we can be grateful.
We Were Soldiers is, ultimately, a powerful and moving experience--once it overcomes its clunky, badly written and cliched first act.
Jurassic Park doesn't have organic flow; it can't disguise its clunky, B-movie soul.
Tropic Thunder is the funniest movie of the summer -- so funny, in fact, that you start laughing before the film itself has begun.
Though McKay and his cast make the most of the material, Step Brothers is constrained by its one-joke concept.
There's room for more than one Brideshead in this far less glamorous day and age.
Nolan wants to prove that a superhero movie needn't be disposable, effects-ridden junk food, and you have to admire his ambition.
You'd have to be a machine for your heart not to melt.
The superhero genre screams for a makeover, or at least a smart deconstruction, but Hancock isn't that movie. It just ups the foolishness ante.

A brave, spectacularly entertaining -- and unexpectedly stirring -- account of Flynt's life that asks us to regard the publisher of Hustler magazine as an invaluable champion of our First Amendment freedoms.
As the body count rises, so does the portentous tone, and the relentlessness of Bekmambetov's overamped style becomes oppressive.
In this distressingly generic spy spoof, it's not Maxwell who's clueless, but the filmmakers.
Its familiar genre pleasures are all on the surface.
It'll shake up your beliefs not just about steroids but about competition, hypocrisy, body obsession and American notions of masculinity.
For all its ambition, the movie ends up using great historical events in the service of a dubious sentimentality.

Speed Racer creates a timeless, visually seductive world suspended somewhere between the pop '60s and the sci-fi future. Its biggest disappointment, strangely enough, is its raison d'être -- the races themselves.
It succeeds in bringing O'Barr's comic-book vision to life, but there's little else going on behind the graphic razzle-dazzle and the moody, ominous soundtrack.
Hollywood has been in love with mobsters since the beginning of movies. But the other side of the equation has seldom been considered. That is, until now.
...Hunt, in her directorial debut, can't seem to decide whether she'd rather make a spicy ethnic dish or bland comfort food.
Its dark, dog-eat-dog vision of the world we live in may give you geopolitical nightmares.
Forest Whitaker, uncorking the power that he usually holds in check, gives a chilling, bravura performance as Ugandan tyrant Idi Amin.

It may be a movie about movies, but the artifice doesn't contradict the movie's plangent emotional realism. Moore's stunning, subtle performance as a woman trapped in the conventions of her time encapsulates the film's brave, double-edged beauty.
Next to Singer's champagne, most recent superhero adventure movies are barely sparkling cider.
Cars inspires more admiration than elation. It dazzles even as it disappoints.

Ron Howard and screenwriter Akiva Goldsman struggle mightily to cram as much as possible of Dan Brown's labyrinthine thriller into a 2-hour-28-minute running time, resulting in a movie both overstuffed and underwhelming.
A minimalist almost-love story told with epic flourishes.
Lucas manages to turn the audience's familiarity to his advantage: like a jigsaw puzzle whose final form has always been known, the fun is in discovering how the last pieces fit.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [A] chilly, caustic, foul-mouthed anatomy of modern romance.
Instead of being moved by Christ's suffering, or awed by his sacrifice, I felt abused by a filmmaker intent on punishing an audience, for who knows what sins.
...the film's urgency can tilt toward shrillness, but nobody else has made the disaster of Guantánamo so painfully vivid.
The second installment was better than the first, and this one is best of all.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Cold Mountain is a movie of episodes, and Minghella pulls off dazzling set pieces: he knows how to infuse violence with emotion, so it never seems gratuitous.
Reloaded is more of a straight-ahead action movie than the original, and it's filled with spectacular mayhem.
Before it degenerates into Indiana Potter and the Chamber of Doom, the movie holds promise.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: You have to honor its mad ambition. But sadly, it feels like a dream too long deferred.
In going home to tell Szpilman's story Polanski seems reborn: once again he's become a filmmaker who matters.
Renee Zellweger and Catherine Zeta-Jones put on quite a show in Rob Marshall's dazzling cinematic rethinking of the 1975 Kander and Ebb musical directed by Bob Fosse.
A delicious cat-and-mouse game flecked with intriguing Oedipal undertones.
There are pleasures to be had in the handsome, heroic The Last Samurai. But they're all on the surface.
Dramatically anorexic.
This indie, a sweet, tart and smart satire about a family of losers in a world obsessed with winning, is an authentic crowd pleaser. There's been no more satisfying American comedy this year.
Miami Vice delivers the thrills, atmosphere and romance it promises, but it doesn't resonate like major Mann.
Pan's Labyrinth unfolds with the confidence of a classical fable, one that paradoxically feels both timeless and startlingly new.
Children of Men leaves too many questions unanswered, yet it has a stunning visceral impact. You can forgive a lot in the face of filmmaking this dazzling.
Soderbergh's skill, intelligence and love for the genre are never in doubt. But, as it turns out, you can't play it again, Sam.
The harder Apocalypto works to shock and excite you, the less shocked and excited you become, until you may find yourself beset by the urge to giggle.
The movie belongs to Hudson as the proud, self-destructive Effie. When she's center stage, Dreamgirls transports you to movie musical heaven.
All the actors get their Big Moments, but verisimilitude goes out the window.
It's preposterous, but never dull: Scott whips the action into a taut, tasty lather.
Though it lacks Wallace and Gromit's charm, its mile-a-minute inventiveness is impressive.
Almodóvar's generous vision isn't just unique, it's color-coordinated.
If Babel were a football game, I'd flag it 15 yards for piling on. Others may want to give it an Oscar. To each his own.
Take the movie's first words to heart: watch closely. You'll be well rewarded.
An epic both raw and contemplative.
If the brush strokes are sometimes a bit sloppy, the grand design of Shortbus endears.
The Departed is Scorsese's most purely enjoyable movie in years.
Wilson's overgrown adolescent, Winslet's bored, discontented wife and Haley's creepy, self-loathing sex offender are complex, deeply flawed characters -- they're the 'little children.'
Thanks to the superb cast and Mottola's deft touch, this modest-looking comedy proves quite memorable.
Piercingly moving and utterly unpolitical, World Trade Center holds us in a fierce grip.
What's remarkable is how immediately, after a full year, The Two Towers seizes your attention, and how urgently it holds you through three seamless, action-packed hours.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This road movie gives you emotional whiplash, and you'll be glad you went along for the ride.
A refreshing summer movie.
A decidedly mixed bag.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: American Beauty is a very funny film that packs an unexpected emotional wallop.
As in the original, the superrealist images beguile us with their bold wit, and the storytelling is so tight, urgent and inventive there doesn't seem to be a wasted moment.
Charismatic!
Kaufman always wanted to keep us guessing, and this movie respects his wishes.
A film of brilliant pieces and dazzling shots!
A film whose tone is out of sync with the simple, ribald conceit and is only mildly amusing at best.
I don't know how a movie this original got made today, but thank God for wonderful aberrations.
South Park has a gag-to-laugh ratio even higher than the new Austin Powers.
Wonder Boys doesn't hit you over the head--its wackiness as well as its humanity slips up on you, catches you off guard.
A likable, lively little ditty -- one theme, some clever variations -- that never wears out its welcome.
A rousing, hugely entertaining movie.
On many levels, Keeping the Faith is a fine film.
If ever there was an example of a director's getting in the way of a story, this is it.
Anyone with a taste for high-risk filmmaking won't want to miss it.
A lumbering, self-important three-hour melodrama that defies credibility at every turn.
A swirling, fluid retelling of the tale that packs an impressive cargo of laughs, thrills and wonders into a watertight 88 minutes!
Like people who compulsively giggle whenever they tell you bad news, the movie runs for cover in lame, comic shtick.
The heat generated by these two attractive stars barely rises above room temperature.
Superbly acted, unblinking and unhysterical, it looks beyond politics into the hearts and minds of the men we needed to call 'the enemy,' and lets us see ourselves.
This is a movie afraid of its own shadows.
Relentless without being overbearing, this is one likely blockbuster that doesn't feel too big for its britches. It's a friendly juggernaut.
It has real passion, real emotion, real terror, and a tactile sense of evil.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
