movie_review_blurb: The humor works better than the horror here - indeed, any seasoned viewer of horror movies won't find this remotely frightening. Still, Krampus is entertaining, with a decent message and a solid ending.

Creed isn't complicated. It's a simple story with just enough humanity sprinkled throughout to capture the hearts and minds of audiences who -- trust me when I say this -- will be cheering at the end.
In this final film, fans will get a satisfying resolution. It's an emotional and dark journey illuminated by an otherworldly performance from Jennifer Lawrence.
Essentially a well-acted Fast and Furious movie, with more British accents. It's good but not great.
With The Visit, Shyamalan has delivered a delicious horror gem so intense that you may accidentally rip the armrests off your seat from clenching them so hard.
All the talent and comedic timing in the world can't rescue this unfocused script from its lack of relevance, poignancy or meaning.
A yarn that is just entertaining enough for you to walk out of the theater satisfied, but not enough to have you begging for more.
A frenetic and rich tale loosely based on real life.
This wanna-be "classic, old-fashioned, grand Hollywood production in the Gothic romance genre" becomes ridiculously graphic and violent.

Black's performance is funny enough to keep the adults superficially interested but if you're over age 12, this movie and plot is too silly to really buy into, although it's a solid choice for the kids.
The Walk, encompassing all the magical elements cinema has to offer, serves as a gorgeous tribute to those buildings loved, admired and missed by so many.

What Sandler does pull off here is an uncommon feat: a sequel that's an improvement over the original, which itself was a solid movie. Your kids will love "Hotel Transylvania 2" and you'll like it, too.

Cooper's performance helps lift the character but as is often the case with a mediocre script and story, it's not clear what exactly this movie wants to be. You'll enjoy the great-looking movie star. The comeback story? Not so much.

Non-Stop is a glorious mix of non-stop suspense, gritty realism, and absurd plot twists.

movie_review_blurb: St. Vincent is the most complete performance of Bill Murray's career.

Transcendence aspires to be a philosophical rumination about the future of artificial intelligence, but it's really just an exercise in superficial intelligence.
Ultimately, Divergent is a mildly entertaining movie that only succeeds because of its talented cast.
[Mark] Wahlberg in particular has really come into his own these past few years, doing the best work of his career. His level of commitment here is second to none.
Director and co-writer David O. Russell deserves all the credit in the world for creating a story, characters and environment in which his actors could truly get lost.
The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug is a vastly different movie than its predecessor, last year's The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, which at times was unexpectedly boring and laborious.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If, however, you believe nothing is sacred when it comes to comedy, then Horrible Bosses 2 will provide you a few laugh-out-loud moments, but not enough of them to justify the price of theater admission.

...the story here is Gyllenhaal, delivering the performance of his career in a career already filled with exceptional performances.

Can we just say this about director James Wan? If you like horror films and you notice he's directed a horror film, make the investment and see it.

One of Ridley Scott's better films in years features one of Matt Damon's best performances.
This is the true reboot of the franchise, the film in which, three movies into his tenure, Daniel Craig becomes the best James Bond there ever was.
Not one frame of this movie is wasted. It feels as if every moment is loaded with conflict: Visually stunning, aurally pleasing, impactful conflict.

Dark and moody, clever and artful with a twist on cliché, "The Drop" is a surprising and tantalizing fall crime drama sprinkled with indelible moments provided by the consistently extraordinary Tom Hardy.

This version of the monster is legendary. On a scale of one to 10, give this Godzilla a solid 9.

The movie fan in me loves Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children. The movie critic in me found a few flaws, but forgivable ones.

Stylish, though innocuous and intermittently feckless.

The story is off the rack, but the plotters' suits are well-tailored.

Rather than surrender his story to the crime or the courtroom, Krokidas scrutinises the ensemble of friends that galvanised the young men into literary vocations and kept the brooding Kammerer at a distance.
The look of this Mitty turns panoramic, but it's generic compared to the 1947 Technicolor version, in which colour and Kaye bounce out from the screen in a then-novel product.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Lisecki directs deftly and lightly, and spreads the jokes around his strong cast.
On a budget that could barely get you on the subway, Madeleine Olnek gets laughs and style out of interplanetary love.
movie_title: Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same (2012)

movie_review_blurb: With a sympathetic and not too heavy hand, Fruitvale Station takes its audience through the constant challenges to black family life - poverty, debt, crime, and the prospect that an encounter with the police can have deadly consequences.
If its dialogue is tepid, its physical comedy is lively, sometimes with real imagination in its colour palette and the odd animals that populate its 3-D landscapes.
Bio-pics always tailor memories. Yet the welcome surprise here is Kutcher, as the barefoot rebel who brought the spirit of psychedelia to technology.
The tone in Sweetwater is as heavy as that firepower, and the film can feel like stiff medicine.
A costumed pageant and the wild spoof of a costumed pageant, Austenland is a clever romp for Jane Austen fans and for those who see Jane Austen mania as an infinitely expanding punchline.
Afternoon Delight the film, about good intentions gone awry, is more motivational therapy than cinema.
The promise of adventure and fun in an exotic land seemed like a good idea, but the result was an uncomfortable jolt.
With lesser voices, Manhunt might have lagged, but personalities and skillful intercutting of archival images fuel its momentum.
In this retreat from Park's earlier wildness (Old Boy), there is a sureness to his directing here, most of the time, as he modulates the volatile family tensions which risk exploding in the house.
This lively documentary breaks no new ground cinematically, yet its mix of discovery and befuddlement should bring more than sports fans to a basketball story.
"Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon," the directorial debut of Mike Myers, is a vaudeville celebrity remembrance of mega-manager Shep Gordon by stars who might have starved without Gordon's help.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A vivid period piece, The Runaways is anything but an extended music video.
A string of cliches, clearly intended for a season that sells those cliches.
Austere and grimly realistic.
This version of Bangkok Dangerous is a respectable genre movie, but not much more.

This film packed with political cliches is unlikely to make a difference to American political culture or its distributor's bottom line, despite a dependable cast of stars including Kevin Costner, Kelsey Grammer, and Dennis Hopper.
[Director Chico] Texeira's ordinary characters have a quiet genuineness and clarity that is rare anywhere in movies these days.
The only thing that differentiates this 'movie' from an infomercial is its unbearable feature length. If you have to sit through it, bring plenty to drink.
Blackburn has assembled a solid cast that pivots from folly into fear with a frightful believability.
Boaz Yakin's dark drama is about the legacy of pain.

[This] story of retreat and redemption, while deeply personal, may mean more to Pellington than to the audience. The miraculous elements in Albert Torres's script that offer hope also strain credulity.

After sitting down with lots of friendly people everywhere he goes, and a few nasty extremists, Spurlock is optimistic. He finds friendship and some real laughs, but the mastermind of the 9/11 attacks eludes him.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Make no mistake: Smiley Face, true to its title, is a silly movie, but not one that's stuck in hammy predictability.

Since Sweeney Todd premiered in 1979, screen serial killers have multiplied like so many disposable razors. Making the audience feel something more than the thrill of watching movie stars is the challenge here, and Sweeney Todd somehow cuts itself short.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There Will Be Blood is a vivid, sprawling parable about greed and moral corrosion.
Feast of Love weaves its way through the frustrated loves of couples in Portland Oregon who don't have much else to do besides reflect on what they have won and lost in romance.
The dazzling images speak eloquently for themselves, even without the director's witty deadpan voice-over.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't break enough rules of the mid-1990's Sundance coming-of-age buddy template to bring any new insights to the bonds of male friendship.
Clever and far more than competent.
As an adaptation of an adaptation, Hairspray beats the odds against turning a musical based on a film into a credible movie.
I haven't seen any recent film about American teenagers in crisis with this kind of economy.
If anything saves this movie, it's the acting.
Yang ties a dozen strands together elegantly with a mostly amateur cast.
Stick with the film, accept the rules of the time and the meditative rhythm of the language that Davies has woven into his story, and you won't be disappointed.
Trust Me is a title that trumpets its own falsehood, and a story true to its subject in scenes that mix grimaces with laughs.
Sentimental but remarkably compelling, the saga of a little man's victory over a corporate giant will ensure that you'll never see your windshield wipers the same way.
Goodman's directing shows a sure hand at the Irish Goodfellas genre, and his actors (including Goodman himself) rally to give the picture plenty of credibility.
Playwright Martin McDonagh's debut feature of his own script shows still-tentative cinematic skills, yet his flair for dialogue and inanity delivers the laughs as the bodies hit the cobblestones.
Even with some fine acting, this film can be a long tiring ride.
Welcome To The Rileys has its heart in the right place, but the drama falters as it tends towards the solemnly earnest.
Daring and potentially offensive, this hilarious satire may be too biting for its own good.
Audiences up to their ears in serial killers may enter this film, thinking they already know them all. Winterbottom will prove them wrong.
The documentary, edited down from some 400 hours, is packed with crowd-pleasing moments.
Stefaniuk, a one-man band as writer, director, actor and author of seven of the film's songs, leavens the schtick of band humour with vampire lore.
The film has the feel of a vaudeville show, with a series of stock characters entering and exiting, hamming for the camera as they go.
Newcomer Cherien Dabis directs Amreeka with a sure hand which takes the film beyond the cliches and sentimentality of the standard immigrant saga.
Whatever Works transcends Allen formulas thanks to David, who is taller, balder and more foul-mouthed than the usual types Allen himself has played.
As a tortured actor, Giamatti is the film's best asset in the marketplace, and French-born, US-trained Sophie Barthes certainly establishes herself as a name to watch with this ambitious debut.
Over-compressed and unoriginal, Thurber's movie of Chabon's novel has turned an imaginative book into ordinary cinema.
Natali's experiment works.
Characters become real enough to draw you in, yet are not deeply drawn enough to make you care.
Doris Dorrie's bittersweet film is a story of mourning and the futility of trying to recover something lost.
Neither terrifying nor inspiring.
The real test of endurance is on the shoulders of an audience challenged to sit through more than two hours of predictable plot turns and recycled sentimentality.
Morris's distillation of long talks with young ex-soldiers and the female general who commanded prisons all over Iraq is among the best documentaries on the Iraq war.
Ballast reminds us that you can find poetry in the unlikeliest and the saddest of places.
Offers up some zinger lines in the trenches of Sin City but fails to live up to its ingenious concept.
A wildly funny parody of low-budget horror cinema.
A tender evocation of youth that turns ponderous as it crawls towards a company's revenge on one of its executives.
If crossbows, strange creatures, and a squeaky-clean young cast are the right elements for a fantasy sequel, then this naive epic is your movie.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Marianne Palka's comedy, which she wrote and stars in, lacks the script, acting and the laughs to rise in the marketplace above similar Sundance-style fare, despite the sado-masochistic streak.
This one has nothing extraordinary about it to compensate for seven years' staleness.
Made In America's ode to opportunity and achievement begs for a deeper reality check.

The jaw-dropping tale of the kidnappings of a famed South Korean actress and her ex-husband, a leading director from Seoul, places screwball intrigue and storybook lustre inside the frame of Cold War tabloid melodrama.

The gripping period film, rigorous in its reconstruction of the recent past, proves that the game of chess can be cinematic in well-edited doses, and that Tobey Maguire as Fischer can sustain a serious, albeit quirky drama.
It's a hybrid reverie of introspection and free association, with moments of charm and insight.
This chilling documentary revisits the fate of the poet Federico Garcia Lorca, executed in 1936, and of others who are known only to their families.
This is not a film that you watch for the style, unless bluntness is your aesthetic. But the details in this intrigue are fascinating.
movie_title: The Trial: The State of Russia vs Oleg Sentsov (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Philippe's tribute to Hollywood's most famous stabbing is an archival feast.
Fate is a blunt instrument here. Yet you still wind up asking for more depth from the characters for whom Hittman is asking you to feel something.
The debut feature by Janicza Bravo takes on a perennial comic genre yet, like its main character, it's best described as a work in progress.
As if the Dardennes came to Brooklyn, only funnier.
25 years later, Yance can't escape the pain of a brother's death - forgotten by so many others - and the frame becomes a confining enclosure for a sibling's anguish coming out of every pore.
Heineman distills cell phone and video imagery from RBSS into a collage of atrocities and fear.
[A] small comedy that hits rare moments of drama ...
The documentary, as it grieves for those losses, points to divisions in American society that are as glaring as ever.
This film is proof that, with the right protagonist, a documentary seems to tell its own story.

Ship of Theseus can be didactic as it nudges audiences toward environmental harmony and economic justice, but it's never preachy or sanctimonious. The credit for that balanced tone goes to its actors, who put real people at the core of these moral tales.

Magnus Carlsen, called the Mozart of chess, became world champion in 2013 at the age of 22. Benjamin Ree's rousing documentary shows us how this taciturn prodigy got there, and how his family keeps him sane.
It's a radiant debut for young newcomer Joe Alwyn, who plays a Texan war hero uneasy in his own land. It's a shakier curtain-raising for Lee's ambitious weaponising of new technologies.

As Layla, Lamis Ammar carries herself with a self-confidence that's tested, to her chagrin, when her hopes collide with tradition. Playing Jalila, veteran actress Ruba Blal-Asfour carries fatalism in her every glance and movement.
Those who find their way to it will see breathtaking surroundings that shape the film's drama.
If kids aren't drawn to one singing animal (or familiar voice), there's always another around the corner, holding up the tentpole.
Gaza Surf Club skirts a direct discussion of politics. It's not necessary.
Little Wing is an odd dramatic cocktail, but Selma Vilhunen finds enough unexpected turns to make this tale worth watching to the finish line.
I Am Not Madame Bovary has a sublime visual elegance, telling its story much of the time with wondrous pictorial effects in a round frame that feels like a magnifying glass.

Chasing Coral is as beautiful as any nature film in its celebration of coral's complexity, and of the undersea architecture that is formed when multiple species of coral create natural multi-level structures of interdependency.
Revelatory and troubling.
You come out of Death In Sarajevo feeling that you've slogged through a familiar stretch of mud - filmed competently, but not memorably.
There may be Lynchian elements in this classic low-budget LA noir, but it's Lola Kirke who impresses the most.
1985 gets the notes right, and its foreboding look takes us back to a dark age. It's a lesson worth remembering. Yet with all the prejudice and pain, the film still feels a lot like a sermon.
Theron will put to rest any doubts about her feel for comedy; the darker the better.

There's a strong dose of anthropology in this documentary, as the filmmakers construct the small world in which Daje lives and interacts with young people like herself - all black, all poor, mostly fatherless.

Green White Green is satire, and satire can't be expected to be definitive, yet this is still a satire whose teeth aren't terribly sharp. But it's a film that puts a political conversation in a Nollywood frame.
Guilty is an epic look at two gruesome killings, made worse by a series of wild miscarriages of justice.
While Veleno draws from a familiar organised crime template, it offers moments of brutality that are all its own.
Olivier Meys has built a drama around a troubling reality of modern China. It's just as troubling when he and Qi Xi take you inside Lina's complex character.
If the title promises a melodrama, this orgy of betrayal certainly is one; yet deft acting and sheer audacity take it beyond standard melodrama fare.
movie_title: The Bold, the Corrupt, and the Beautiful (2017)

movie_review_blurb: McArdle lurches around the language of the music video in a stylish feature debut.

Ines and Emilie have tensions between them which are uncomfortably alive, and Langseth's script is a gnawing reminder that, even when the date of death is set, family quarrels and resentments can still be corrosive.
While it's no Raging Bull, it is fun, if you're willing to roll with the punches.
This stolid narrative approach feels appropriate for a film that is as much testimony as it is drama.
movie_title: A Season in France (Une Saison en France) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary of stunning beauty and tragic violence ...
Cerebral and emotional, Tempestad is a road movie fuelled by the memories of unjust punishment. It's a bumpy but illuminating ride.

In a field where the new is celebrated, The Circle is about the threat of ceding control of personal data to a business monopoly. Now we've seen it once again, with marquee stars. It's still a threat.
The drama sets up a psychological dead end, with doleful strings tracking the emotions.

Burdge is game for this mania, and so is Bonnard, yet the wild process of love as horror lacks something at its core, as if a young director is trying his hardest to get the notes right and then play them louder.
Meyers's drama depends mostly on what it doesn't show you, and it works.

Perhaps MacLachlan was after a visual vocabulary that was as limited as his film's dialogue. In doing so, he's sold his story short. This crop feels like it needed more time to come out of the ground.
The Lovers is shrewd, even if it's not altogether satisfying. It reveals lots of promise in this young director.

This eighth instalment of The Fast And The Furious franchise, directed by F Gary Gray, is reliable, containing plenty of deafening car pile-ups to keep the core audience satisfied while also stirring witty new flourishes into the old recipe.
This no-budget spoof of violent gonzo promotional culture is in your face, as the saying goes, and the blood is all part of the punch-line.
In the visually stunning Atlantic, the ocean is frame, medium and subject. It is also the barrier to a Moroccan windsurfer who seeks a life beyond his impoverished village.
Even by cult documentary standards, this one finds absurd depths in the peddling of enlightenment.
Custody may feel long, but it's short by the standard of waiting times at Family Court.
The American frontier is as bloody as ever in Slow West, John Maclean's lean and lyrical coming of age story.
Anesthesia comes from the heart, as few films do these days.
The surprise in Maggie is Abigail Breslin, playing a teenager who flares and burns with dread as she becomes aware of the horror of her infection.
Monahan is nothing if not well-read, and the battle between Thomas and Jack is a duel of words, with plenty of guns to keep the western spirit going.
The venerable Parisian couture house Christian Dior gets a makeover in Dior And I, which follows a new design director's rough journey to the runway.
Turbo Kid is a wild enough burlesque that the audience can ignore a few things that don't seem quite right.
[A] delicately calibrated portrait of dissolution which points to the versatility of writer/director Alex Ross Perry.
A competent feature debut - elegantly filmed and paced to keep viewers with Franco on an improbable ride.
An unprecedented portrait of the actor, culled from 200 hundreds of hours of recordings that Brando made by and about himself.
The grim film is sure to make the audience uncomfortable.
A tour de force that takes Maddin's ambition through a maze of magical melodrama.
The Hunting Ground takes a somber tone, and delivers alarming testimony and statistics.

Nick Cave says he isn't interested in things that he understands. Yet this distillation of the man himself -- reflective and sensitive, and inventive -- tells you much about an artist's understanding of his art.
It's ambitious, it's bloody and it's confusing.
With barely any sex on the screen, the film suggests more than it shows and, despite its small canvas, is a stylistic coup for the director's low-budget ambitions.
The strong ensemble cast adds to the verisimilitude of a place that you would rather experience on the screen than in the inside.
A pile of knockoff flourishes which adds up to to a lot of manure in the fields of Montana.

Failing to measure up to heartbreaking classics about the aged pushed out of their homes by the new - Leo McCarey's Make Way For Tomorrow (1937)and Vittorio de Sica's Umberto D (1952) - Ruth & Alex is mostly real estate lite.
Del Toro in the role of the portly coke king raises this narco kill-fest above the level of a film made according to a cook book.
Gere is earnest, but at least he's not being warm and fuzzy. The actor's unshaven face puts a face on a problem that the public has grown accustomed to ignoring.
This Brooklyn tale earns a Bronx cheer.
An Open Secret is nothing short of a smoking gun.
Censored Voices is a reminder that glorious myths of wars and the men who fight them wither under scrutiny, in Israel and everywhere else.
Deftly edited, and filmed with a feel for the deadly volatility of drug violence.
Big Game is great fun, yet Helander in his second feature shows that he can handle monumental logistics as well as laughs.

Taksler, a producer on The Daily Show, shows Youssef as a warmhearted and effortlessly amusing man, and his satire is the sugar coating around the bitter truth that democratic revolution has failed in Egypt and almost every other Arab country.
Chilling and prodigiously researched ...
Critical scrutiny has never hurt Holmes's career. It still won't, now that she's a director.
This well-meaning debut feature about following your dreams just treads water.
The result is not altogether intoxicating.
The Fits benefits from scrapping a three-act structure and avoiding crescendos and easy moralism.
Linklater does connect you with the fun that he must have had in those days. If you can take the testosterone, you'll have a good time.
As a moral tale, The Wave warns of the consequences when ordinary people underestimate a behemoth.
Mr. Right is aiming to be a tent-pole film that just happens to have a lot of dead bodies and just as many dutiful shots of the New Orleans skyline. The gambit may just work.
The closer the documentary gets to individual musicians and their histories, the more engaging it becomes.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fifi Howls From Happiness evokes feelings in exile of the liveliness of culture in Tehran decades earlier, without a breath of nostalgia.
It's Angelou's voice that matters here, and the doc captures it.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 12-14-12, like 9/11, is a monumental date. Snyder revisits it on an intimate scale.
The element of magic - handled skillfully by Latimore and by Dillard, a magician since childhood - is enough of a novelty and an expansion of the gangbanger playbook to give Sleight some legs.
Like Cai, the doc is a crowd-pleaser which reveals its complexities in a careful viewing.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film gives us a portrait of rural austerity, but even in Davies's limited palette of grey and brown, there is a near-infinite spectrum of hues in dusky interiors and in the surrounding hills.
A rare kind of documentary -- muscular and refined, and a splendour for the eyes.
It's an inspiring story, acted with heart and grit by Paige and Wood, and film directed with adroitness by Rozema in a ruin of a set in the woods.

Hester's goal was to convince politicians that gay people are like everyone else. In its ultra-mainstream style, and now in its argument for equality (which most of America endorses today), this solidly acted drama drives that point home.
As sweet as a meditation on death can be.
[A] sputtering comedy

At the core of this clumsy debut feature, there is still the vital insight that philanthropy in America can be an addiction for the rich who seek cleansing and approval, and vent their fury when they don't get it unconditionally.

You're left at the end of the film with the horror that a lone killer ended the lives of people who came out to watch a Batman movie. You also have the ominous sense that any of the lone souls in this suburb could have lashed out.
Brawls and bravado aside, Pollock has the stiffness of an official biography.
